column2:
By typing in your Prolific ID and submitting, you acknowledge that:

- You are at least 18 years of age.
- You have read and understood this information.
- You agree to participate and allow your anonymous responses to be used for academic research.
column3:
Please read carefully before continuing.
This survey will take approximately 30 minutes to complete. We ask that you respond thoughtfully and seriously — your input is highly valuable to our research.
Participants who complete the survey attentively will receive fair compensation through Prolific.
Are you willing to proceed?

(1 = Most Unsupportive, 10 = Most Supportive)

Universal healthcare refers to a system in which all individuals have access to necessary health services without financial hardship, typically funded by public resources such as taxes.

(1 = Most Unsupportive, 10 = Most Supportive)

column4: I've lived in the same one-bedroom apartment in Midtown for the past five years. When I first moved in, it was a good option for me since I was just entering my career and wanted to be close to downtown and have a relatively easy commute. Now that I'm more settled in my career as a software engineer, I still like the neighborhood and the independence of having my own place. While sometimes I do think about buying a property, the Houston real estate market is very competitive and I have not yet found my ideal match. For now, renting is still the most convenient option for me.

column4: I moved from Green Bay about 50 miles north to Marinette in June 2023. I had been sharing a modest ranch-style house with a married couple who are close friends of mine. Now I share a big two-story house with a friend. I mostly live upstairs and we share the downstairs kitchen and laundry area. The spouses I'd been living with were fighting a lot and it had become very unpleasant. I moved here because I couldn't afford my own place, and it was very tough to find a roommate at my age (64 at the time).

column4: Four years ago we moved from a typical midwestern suburban home in a subdivision to a condominium complex.  The condos are attached two and three story buildings in a unit collection intended to resemble an Italian village.  The buildings are loosely circled around a large swimming pool and a fountain (this is in Florida).  This was quite a change for my husband and I, who both grew up in a very suburban environment outside of a large midwestern city.  We were not used to certain aspects of the situation, such as the close proximity to neighbors, no real exterior space of our own, and exorbitant HOA costs.  We have mostly adjusted and settled in, but there was some culture shock.

column4: Over the past five years I’ve stayed in the same townhouse in Chinatown Los Angeles. I haven’t moved, but my rent has gradually risen from about $900 per month five years ago to $1,500 today. Each year when the lease renewed, the rent increase was a reminder of L.A.’s tight housing market, but I’ve chosen to stay put for the stability it provides and to keep my commute to school and work manageable.
